title: What Does This Say About the Future?
name: SPY_Master
contents:
As many of you know, this week Warren Buffet increased his stake in the oil and natural gas company Occidental Petroleum Corp. (OXY).
Warren Buffettâ€™s holding company Berkshire Hathaway now owns about 21% of the company.

In light of Warren Buffet's purchase, I analyzed the chart of OXY to see what he or his analysts might be seeing. As I'll explain below, what I found was concerning for multiple reasons.


This is the yearly chart of the entire price history of OXY. Each candle represents the price action for one year.


It is important to log-adjust your charts in general, but especially when analyzing higher timeframes. Below is a log-adjusted chart.


Since OXY is also a dividend-paying stock, analyzing its history over such a long time period over which it has paid dividends means we need to adjust for dividends as well. Below is a dividend-adjusted chart.


Now that the chart has been properly adjusted, we can do our chart analysis.

Looking at this chart, I immediately noticed that OXY is about to undergo a major Fibonacci extension . I will explain more below.

First, I applied Fibonacci levels from the lowest low to the highest high.



You can see my Fibonacci levels applied in the chart above (I hid the 0.5 level because that is actually not a Fibonacci level).

I noticed that, during the COVID-19 Pandemic, OXY's price bounced off of the golden ratio and then proceed to move much higher. See the below chart.


In my experience, this type of price action is rare and usually proceeds what is called an "S-curve jump". Without getting too deep into higher-level mathematics behind S curves, in short, an S-curve jump basically means a major breakout may occur on the time frame in which it appears. Following an S-curve jump, prices can move much higher. Since this particular jump is occurring on a high timeframe, be mindful that the move can seem slow, and there can even be periods of weeks or months of declines even though a breakout on the yearly timeframe is underway. Perhaps this is why Warren Buffet accumulated so many shares of this company. Warren Buffet is long-term investor and so investing based on the yearly chart is most consistent with a multi-decadal investment strategy like his.

To help you visualize what an S-curve jump looks like I've illustrated it below. This chart is purely illustrative and is not my actual price projection for OXY (it's impossible to accurately predict price so far into the future).


As shown above, price jumps from one S-curve to another, leading to significant increases in price.

Interestingly, the second S-curve often starts at the golden ratio retracement of the previous S-curve.


Once the price successfully jumps an S-curve, the price increases can be monumental. Actually, it is during the period after price jumps an S-curve that most people get wealthy from their investment. It's how 'millionaires are created'. However, price tends to falter at each successive Fibonacci extension . Below I've highlighted an example of this using Bitcoin which moves almost entirely based on Fibonacci extensions and retracements.


Notice how following a perfect golden ratio retracement, Bitcoin moved up to nearly the next Fibonacci extension level before collapsing back down a Fibonacci level. You can see clearly that price has been hovering right on a Fibonacci level in recent months.

Going back to OXY, we can use a regression channel to try to validate the hypothesis that price may move much higher in the coming year(s). See the chart below.


A regression channel merely measures how far above or below its mean an asset is currently priced. Each blue line represents a standard deviation from the mean. We can see that OXY's price recently reached its mean (the red line) before retracing back down. Similar to retracement after reaching Fibonacci extensions, it is common for price to retrace some of its move each time it hits a higher standard deviation.

What's noteworthy is that although OXY's price has come all the way back up near its all-time high, the regression channel shows that this level is now merely the price's mean. See the below chart.


This suggests that, from a mean regression perspective, OXY's price can rise much higher before becoming as overextended as it was the last time it was priced at this level.

If we conclude that OXY's price is poised to go much higher, what does this say about the future? What might spiraling energy prices say about the Federal Reserve's, and other central banks', ability to fight inflation? By buying OXY while the Fed is trying to fight inflation , is Warren Buffet fighting the Fed? What might higher energy prices say about supply issues in the long term? Might higher energy prices reflect a prolonged period of deglobalization, or perhaps, something worse like geopolitical conflict? What might the consequences of higher energy prices be for climate change? Will higher energy prices incentive more investment in alternative energy options like solar, wind, nuclear and hydrogen?

One thing is for certain: The scope of monetary easing that we saw over the past couple of decades is unprecedented in history, and it has created an asset bubble that is unfathomable. I will leave you with two additional charts. One shows how low U.S. GDP growth has been over the past couple of decades, and yet how high its stock market has climbed due to monetary easing.




How do you soft land a stock market that's risen into the stratosphere? By pushing it gently to the surface of the moon.

title: Here's How Far the S&P 500 May Fall
name: SPY_Master
contents:
I have been asked how low the S&P 500 could go in the coming economic downturn.

In terms of stock market price action, all major economic downturns are merely Fibonacci retracements on the yearly chart.

In fact, we can predict with a reasonably high degree of certainty the bottom for the next recession before it even begins! That's because stock market bottoms are predetermined by past price action. In the case of SPX , the next stock market bottom was predetermined nearly 90 years ago.

I will try to prove this below using the replay function that @TradingView provides for charts.

So let's go back in time.


Here is what the stock market looked like in 1929 right after the Black Tuesday stock market crash.


Around this time, market participants felt not much unlike they feel today: The stock market had been on a decade-long rip higher but just had a bad past several months. For the most part, most of the profits from a decade of prolific growth were intact. Though fear was high and continuing to mount, many market participants still had hope that the stock market would recover and continue its trend higher in the next year. Little did they know that they were sitting on the precipice of the most dramatic crash in stock market history...


To see what happened let's apply Fibonacci levels. See the chart below where I placed log-adjusted Fibonacci levels. (One should always use log-adjusted Fibonacci levels when analyzing the S&P 500 in general, but especially on higher timeframes).



Unfortunately, the stock market would proceed to crash relentlessly for years. Here's what the chart looked like precisely at the stock market bottom in 1931.


The magnitude of the market crash is hard to overstate. Indeed, many people's lives were ruined by it. Some investors who lost everything even committed suicide. At this point, virtually all market participants were certain the stock market would never go back up to new all-time highs. But it's usually precisely at these points of universal despair that significant stock market bottoms form.

Despite all the calamity and then despair, the stock market was merely undergoing Fibonacci retracement on the yearly timeframe. As you can see below, it retraced, and then quickly rebounded.



Now let's fast forward over a half-century to the what's often considered the second-worst stock market crash in history: the infamous Black Monday on October 19, 1987.

To put this date into perspective I've drawn a line up to this level on the 1931 chart.


Let's fill in all the candles to see what happened on Black Monday in 1987.

As you can see in the chart below, during the 1980s, after Fed chairman Volcker successfully contained the inflation of the 1970s, the stock market ripped higher.


However, unbeknownst to many, the stock market was beginning to approach its 2nd Fibonacci extension (or 2nd Fibonacci spiral). These important Fibonacci levels act as magnets to which price is mathematically attracted. As market participants' greed and optimism took hold, the stock market went up parabolically.

Everyone was getting rich.

Derivatives trading exploded because of market participants' extreme greed.

Then, in August 1987, the 2nd Fibonacci extension was reached.


Here's a close-up:

After August 1987, the stock market entered a typically volatile period of the year (September and October). Suddenly, everyone's greed shifted to panic. Everyone wanted to sell all at once. Derivatives trading became chaotic, so much so that the volume overwhelmed the exchanges to such an extreme level that price discovery became virtually impossible.

The stock market crashed.

It caused the highest volatility spike ever recorded. The predecessor to the VIX , the VXO , reached an intraday high of 172.

The VIX today is 28.

The second-worst stock market crash in history following the Great Depression happened exactly at the second Fibonacci extension .



Now let's fast forward to the year 2000. Dotcom stocks were ballooning as market participants began to realize that an e-commerce revolution was happening. Again, market participants' greed and optimism took hold, the stock market went up parabolically.

Everyone was getting rich.

But remember the chart from the Great Depression? See below.



Well, there are two Fibonacci extension levels (2.414 and 2.618) from that chart that were sending a warning nearly 70 years later.



These Fibonacci levels would contain price action of not one but two economic recessions: The Dotcom Bust and the Great Recession



All the chaos of Dotcom companies going bankrupt and of financial services firms collapsing during the Great Recession was contained within two Fibonacci levels that were predetermined over 70 years prior to these events unfolding.


Chaotic and calamitous events that characterize every stock market crash are part of the predictable and orderly of ebb and flow that characterizes Fibonacci extension and retracement. Mathematically, the Fibonacci sequence turns irrational and disorderly numbers into orderly and perfect ratios.


Now fast forward to 2021. Decades of monetary easing have caused the stock market to explode higher, even while volume was shrinking. But yet again, market participants' greed and optimism took hold, the stock market went up parabolically.

Everyone was getting rich.


The stock market had risen so fast and so far that the Dotcom bubble was largely forgotten as stocks of start-up companies with no earnings went to the moon upon initial public offering, and as companies with negative cash flow became more valuable than blue chip companies.

Indeed, the S&P 500 chart was so parabolic that the most calamitous period in the stock market history -- the Great Depression -- was not even visible on it.

Despite not being visible, except on log-adjusted charts, the price action from Great Depression 90 years prior, was again sending a warning that few noticed: the 3rd Fibonacci spiral had been reached.


Despite limitless monetary easing causing the stock market to overthrow the 3rd Fibonacci extension , as usual, this level acted as a magnet for price, and the stock market came back down to it once market participants' greed turned into fear.

The result was one of the worst first 6 months of the year in stock market history.



Indeed, the June 2022 "bottom" occurred exactly at the 3rd Fibonacci extension .


So how far might we retrace in the coming economic downturn? If the 3rd Fibonacci extension fails to support the stock market, then we will likely decline to the 2.618 Fibonacci level.



We are still relatively at a market top, and as usual, at market tops, few market participants accept the possibility that the stock market could ever retrace down so far to the previous Fibonacci level.

Ironically, years later, once the stock market has indeed retraced down so far, few market participants accept the possibility that the stock market could ever extend back up and reach new all-time highs.

This is simply the nature of the endless Fibonacci extension and retracement roller coaster that is the stock market.




For more information about the math and theory behind the Fibonacci spiral, also known as the Golden Spiral, you check out this Wikipedia article on the Golden Spiral: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golden_spi...
Comment: The selling may continue until at least the golden ratio retracement has been achieved. August and September have been months characterized by capitulation.
Comment:
Comment:

Comment: Now that we returned back to the 3rd Fibonacci spiral, the next phase will be that we drop below this level to form a lower wick on the yearly chart. The yearly chart will tend to want to close near this level. This means that more downside is likely from late September into October, and then price will rise in November and into December to close the year near this Fibonacci level or slightly below or above it. In terms of how low price can drop in 2022 before finding some kind of strong support, keep an eye out for 3566 on the S&P 500. I would be quite surprised if price crashes below this level with no bounce at all. This level is a golden ratio retracement from the COVID bottom to the January 2022 top. If price respects this level strongly, then there is a bull case to be made going into the close of the year. Whereas if price crashes past this level, then I would be quite concerned.

It is my belief that if the S&P 500 does not find its ultimate bottom around 3566, then it will be quite clear that the stock market has begun a years-long process of retracing stock market gains. As always, anything can happen, and there will surely be bull runs along the way. This is not financial advice, do your own research. Don't use anything I post to buy or sell. This is just my open-source journal here. I love seeing charts in the comments, so feel free to drop one!

Comment: All of this market panic created by fear of spiraling inflation, an energy crisis, a monetary crisis, sovereign debt and bond crisis, war, deglobalization, and climate change, may seem like a lot.

During times like this, it's important to know stock market history. Throughout stock market history things often feel this way. Volatility is common almost every September and October. Indeed the current VIX level is actually quite low compared to periods of worse stock market panic.

While I do see further economic downturn in the future, there are nonetheless great opportunities to invest in beaten-down stocks right now! I am currently loading up on beaten-down stock in my self-directed IRA, which has a time horizon of about 30 years before I start to cash out. In this account, I only ever buy. I never sell stocks from it.

Here are some crashing stocks that look like great long-term investment candidates to dollar-cost average on within an IRA:

SWK
VFC
SMG
MPW
WPC
CHTR
FDX
O
FIS

Could these all go lower? Yes, absolutely. In which case, buy more!

You may ask, but what if some of these companies go bust?!

My answer: That's fine. Investing is not about being perfect, it's about having probability on your side. All you need is for just a few of these stocks to simply recover their losses and the rest can go bankrupt and you'd still be profitable. Most likely, all of these companies will persist and over 10, 20, or 30 or more years, many of them will rise by multiples of where they're trading today. I screened these companies to confirm that they all outperform the money supply over time. So once the Fed does pivot (and it will) and restarts the money printer, these stocks will scream higher.

Finally, you may ask: Why buy now and not later at a cheaper price?

My answer: Well while things can get cheaper, but they also might not. No one ever knows the exact bottom. For a stock like SMG, it has already dropped to a level that has a significant economic downturn priced in. In fact, SMG's drop is equivalent to the S&P 500's drop during the Great Depression on a standard deviation basis. Knowing this makes it a perfect candidate for an IRA.

You should always contribute the maximum to an IRA regardless of if you expect the market to get cheaper. This is because, if the market does get cheaper, you will have a large basket of holdings that you can convert to Roth, and then benefit from tax-free growth. Waiting until the market bottom, assuming one can even predict the exact bottom, is not ideal because you can only contribute a certain amount to an IRA in a given year. Thus, you will not benefit as much from buying right at the bottom, as you would averaging down and accumulating a much larger portfolio and then converting to a Roth at the bottom. The only strategy that is time-tested is dollar cost-averaging for an IRA.

So the moral of the story is that during market crashes there is much opportunity to build wealth, and one of the best means to do so is an IRA.

Not financial advice, just my thoughts.

After a drop from the market top, most market participants share this same type of continued exuberance. In fact, this is called the denial stage of the economic grief cycle and it always occurs after a decline from the market top has occurred, but while there's still lots of optimism that the market will go back up.   Indeed, those holding losing long positions can easily get angered by posts like mine which merely apply Fibonacci levels to a chart and objectively show that a lot more downside is at least possible.  Anything can happen, and my post is objectively indicating to keep open the possibility that we are undergoing a Fibonacci retracement on the yearly chart.

Indeed, we've not yet had capitulation as there's not been sustained VIX term structure backwardation. When this occurs, many market participants begin to panic sell. It's not until after market participants like this individual flip and begin saying there's no hope that I'd be confident that a market bottom is in. That occurs in the despair/depression stage.

I think every single market participant should listen to Warren Buffet discussing the stock market crash of 1929, if for no other reason than to always keep things in perspective: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1uMFR69vC3w

Always appreciate your questions and contrary opinions. 

Based on my charting experience I would be surprised if SPY closed 2022 as high as 413-430. The highest I'm comfortable with considering realistic is around 380. I think that the yearly candle will to gravitate to the 3rd Fibonacci spiral, and that value is in the 360s. Just as likely as SPY is to overshoot the 360s, it could also undershoot and close below the 360s. If SPY closes the year at 430 as you believe, then I'd believe that the bull run continues. However, I'm just not seeing this confirmed in any long-term charts. 

The stock market (S&P 500) is actually just an oscillator of the money supply, and yes, it is definitely guided by Fibonacci levels and logarithmic growth patterns. Whenever I look at a chart, these patterns are all I ever see. They're literally everywhere. To an untrained eye though, the stock market looks random or chaotic. When I look at a chart I see differential equations and Fibonacci spirals.

Comment here when the year closes so we can see how our predictions played out. Best of luck with your trades!","comment_ast":{"type":"root","children":[{"type":"user","params":{"name":"louistran_016","link":"/u/louistran_016/"}},", Always appreciate your questions and contrary opinions. 

Based on my charting experience I would be surprised if SPY closed 2022 as high as 413-430. The highest I'm comfortable with considering realistic is around 380. I think that the yearly candle will to gravitate to the 3rd Fibonacci spiral, and that value is in the 360s. Just as likely as SPY is to overshoot the 360s, it could also undershoot and close below the 360s. If SPY closes the year at 430 as you believe, then I'd believe that the bull run continues. However, I'm just not seeing this confirmed in any long-term charts. 

The stock market (S&P 500) is actually just an oscillator of the money supply, and yes, it is definitely guided by Fibonacci levels and logarithmic growth patterns. Whenever I look at a chart, these patterns are all I ever see. They're literally everywhere. To an untrained eye though, the stock market looks random or chaotic. I am a little uncomfortable commenting here because I only formulate hypotheses based on charts, data and equations, but these questions require me to speculate and provide my personal opinions.

I think that the most disruptive technological shift in human productivity occurred at the start of the industrial revolution. It was then that the human population reached an inflection point and went into logistic growth.  In terms of the disruption on productivity that current technically is having, that is within the realm of speculation. Before even venturing a guess, I'd first need to see a chart that shows real GDP accelerating.  From a regression perspective GDP growth has been stagnating since the Great Recession (see regression channel below). 

https://www.tradingview.com/x/NhVHM4sI/

We're currently 2 standard deviations below the mean in terms of GDP growth. 

World population is similarly falling below the 2 standard deviation level, possibly suggesting that as population growth declines, so too will productivity.

https://www.tradingview.com/x/Yeloxbin/

Yet, thanks to monetary easing the stock market has skyrocketed to 2 standard deviations above its mean (see below chart), despite slowing real GDP growth and slowing population growth.

https://www.tradingview.com/x/wBaExSNX/

If anything, I see a danger in the monetary easing creating such a massive asset bubble while GDP slows.  In the face of spiraling inflation, central banks are trapped because they cannot fight inflation without deflating the asset bubble.  

Right now there is a public outcry against inflation, but the public outcry against deflation of the asset bubble and their perceived wealth will be much worse.  Thus central banks are trapped in a Catch-22.

It is during periods such as this that fascism and communism rise, and the stage becomes set for global conflict.","comment_ast":{"type":"root","children":[{"type":"user","params":{"name":"louistran_016","link":"/u/louistran_016/"}},", I am a little uncomfortable commenting here because I only formulate hypotheses based on charts, data and equations, but these questions require me to speculate and provide my personal opinions.

Tech needs to unwind a lot more before it meets my IRA buy criteria. I only buy at deep discount for my IRA, or otherwise when I expect an asset to undergo significant Fibonacci extension on a log scale. Tech meets neither criteria for my standards yet. I personally think AAPL is the biggest single-stock risk in the market right now. Unbelievable cash flow, fortress balance sheet, strong growth potential.  When the stock market started declining investors started flocking to Apple for relative safety. Little do they know that they've boarded the Titanic. It's been nearly 20 years since Apple last touched its yearly EMA ribbon. I'm hard-pressed to find any stock with such a long, relentless bull run. 

Apple's been the beneficiary of the decades-long ETF experiment, which in turn has been the beneficiary of the decades-long monetary easing experiment.  Since Apple is the largest holding of numerous ETFs if Apple falls it will take down numerous ETFs and mutual funds, and likewise if ETFs fall, they will take down Apple.  I love Apple as a company as much as anyone else, but I know my charts really well, and I'm certain that Apple is going to disappoint a whole lot of people in the years to come. I value your opinion but respectfully disagree.  I think Apple is going to stagnate and decline for years to come.  What I will concede, though, is that when an asset is relatively near the peak of its bubble, it always appears to have extremely strong fundamentals.  Assets never peak with weak fundamentals.  So your statement about its strong fundamentals is unconvincing in terms of assessing whether or not it has peaked in inherent value. Also consider that even though Apple's fundamentals are iron clad, being the largest holding of numerous ETFs means that Apple can decline significantly if those ETFs decline.  ETF investors are passive and are not investing based directly on Apple's fundamentals. 

In terms of inherent value, Apple peaked on December 13, 2021.  For years, its subsequent peaks in inherent value will be lower and lower and lower until it becomes undervalued.  What this means, believe it or not, is that even if Apple's price goes up over time, that increase will be less than inflation/money supply growth such that holders of Apple stock will lose purchasing power over time.  Apple will fail, therefore, to be a wealth-building vehicle for many years to come.

Trust me or not, I am quite good at analyzing this stuff.  It's not my opinion or how I personally feeling which has led me to this conclusion, it is merely data and charts.","comment_ast":{"type":"root","children":[{"type":"user","params":{"name":"louistran_016","link":"/u/louistran_016/"}},", I value your opinion but respectfully disagree. Great question! Yes, it is my hypothesis that the market tops and bottoms (pivot points on the yearly chart) do not depend on yet unknown economic events, as much as they conform to mathematical functions and to Fibonacci retracement and extension levels.  

All assets move in some kind of a mathematical function. This not speculative because mathematical functions are defined by and are meant to characterize past price data. Therefore these functions are fit to past data, but in turn provide predictive value. (The functions to which I am referencing here are ones in which an assetâ€™s value is measured in U.S. dollars, or some other currency, on the y-axis and time on the x-axis).

Some assets move in exponential decay, or in other words, the value of the asset as measured in U.S. dollars declines over time at an accelerating rate with zero as the asymptote. During this late phase of an assetâ€™s growth, one of three things can occur: 

(1) The price of an asset continues to stagnate endlessly (meaning it increases by lesser and lesser amounts over time as it perpetually nears its asymptote); 

(2) The price of an asset begins to decline substantially as the function converts to exponential decay (Typically, if the stock of a company undergoes this type of event the company will proceed to bankruptcy and eventually be delisted. The only stocks that I have ever seen undergo this conversion and yet still be listed on the stock exchanges are those of banks, and that is because the Federal Reserve prefers to keep banks in existence regardless of their growth potential in an attempt to maintain the stability of the banking system); or 

(3) The price of an asset â€œjumpsâ€ to the next S-curve (Jumping to the next S-curve is the most bullish scenario and can happen once despair shifts back to mania.  There are some interesting articles about what fundamentally causes this, but you can tell when this is about to occur using charts. Right before the â€œjumpâ€ occurs, price forms a bull flag or pennant on the log scale with the MA exp ribbon supporting price. Indeed, jumping S-curves is a natural phenomenon of growth, Iâ€™ve seen it happen many times in the charts of total cases of COVID-19. Each new strain of the virus that was more contagious than the previous dominant strain usually resulted in an S-curve jump in the total number of cases).

In all three scenarios, price undergoes Fibonacci retracement to some degree. There is one stock, in particular, that is undergoing this right now and which is about to reach its inflection point, or "break out". It is poised to make those investing in it millionaires in the future. I plan to publish a post on this stock in the future.

Some assets that are in logarithmic bull flags or pennant patterns right now also include blockchain assets, particularly those that are laying the foundation for d-Apps, de-fi and DAOs. While the vast majority of cryptocurrencies are essentially worthless, there are a few that are so valuable that it is possible that they will make anyone who accumulates them among the most wealthy individuals in the years and decades to come -- when humans interact almost exclusively through virtual or augmented reality means. I am currently researching cryptocurrencies and plan to post my findings on here in the future.

So while most analysts would argue that the market is obviously responding to the Fed hiking rates and not to Fibonacci levels. It is actually these Fibonacci levels, that when reached, forced the Fed to pivot. Once the stock market reached its 3rd Fibonacci spiral, a pivot to monetary tightening was inevitable in the near future. So, I argue that mathematical functions guide the markets and price action. At best, the introduction of random events merely causes market participants to move the market toward the next Fibonacci retracement or extension level vis-Ã -vis their greed or fear in response to the event.  The event itself is largely interchangeable with any other event that causes greed or fear of a similar magnitude. It is actually these Fibonacci levels, that when reached, forced the Fed to pivot. Once the stock market reached its 3rd Fibonacci spiral, a pivot to monetary tightening was inevitable in the near future. So, I argue that mathematical functions guide the markets and price action.  Central banks are totally trapped.  The Fed can't pivot or else inflation will spiral.  

Here's the situation in the UK right now: After decades of monetary easing -- to such an extreme degree that the amount of assets on the Bank of England's balance sheet is the highest in the 322-year period for which records exist -- inflation is now spiraling out of control. Inflation has reached the highest levels in 40 years. Despite the highest inflation in over a generation, the UK has chosen now, of all possible times, to cut taxes.  Cutting taxes during spiraling inflation is sort of like trying to blow out a fire.  The fire gets worse.  With lower taxes, people now have more money to spend, which keeps inflation higher for longer.  As a result, the UK's bond yields rose because following the tax cuts, the market anticipated more hiking would be needed to quell inflation.  Rather than actually hike rates more, the Bank of England chose to buy bonds to bring yields back down.  This is like trying to drown out a fire by dousing it with gasoline.  Since banks and credit markets typically peg their lending rates to these yields, this monetary easing action incentivizes cheaper credit.  By incentivizing cheaper credit, more money is created through lending, more money in the system will in turn cause inflation to spiral yet even higher.  In fact, most money is created through lending.  This in turn creates a negative feedback loop whereby the U.S. Federal Reserve cannot pivot to easing because inflation continues to worse. It causes the Fed to hike more for longer.  This in turn puts yet even more pressure on Japan, the UK, and the rest of the world's currencies, and in turn, they may continue to ease yet even more. In a worst-case scenario, hyperinflation may occur. 

Meanwhile, the least developed countries will experience shortages of food and commodities as these become unattainable due to high inflation. These countries do not possess the reserves needed to counter a strengthening dollar, like Japan and the UK.

After seeing the Bank of England and Bank of Japan both respond to high inflation with more monetary easing, I am increasingly convinced that this situation is going to spiral into a full-blown monetary crisis. 

Indeed, this is the dollar milkshake theory that Brent Johnson has been warning would come for years: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xxzy3sLs4Bs","comment_ast":{"type":"root","children":[{"type":"user","params":{"name":"akikostas","link":"/u/akikostas/"}},",  Central banks are totally trapped. These are all great questions about the future but no one knows the future for certain. 

The dollar's growing value is related both to the disparity in monetary conditions (U.S. Federal Reserve tightening more than its counterparts) but also, more simply, it reflects a shortage of dollars.  Most commodities are priced and settled in dollars, so when inflation spirals, buying commodities requires more dollars.  But since inflation also causes the Federal Reserve to reduce the supply of dollars to contain inflation domestically, this dynamic can spiral into a monetary crisis.  Japan is trying to devalue the dollar by increasing its supply via selling Treasuries. But while this may help Japan in the short term, this also has the consequence of keeping commodity prices higher for longer. Since the central banks of the UK and Japan have chosen to fight inflation with more monetary easing, this means that for the foreseeable future, inflation continues.  The more inflation spirals higher the worst things get. Once the public expects more inflation, it becomes a self-fulfilling prophecy.  People save less and spend more because they know their dollars will become worth less over time.  People demand more pay, which in turn leads to higher prices for longer.  Companies raise prices with the expectation of inflation.  The spiral gets worse and worse and worse over time. There are only two solutions to spiraling inflation that do not involve making it worse. One is increasing the supply of commodities (not easy to do in an increasingly hostile and deglobalized world, also this will have negative climate change implications) or to crush demand so severely that even though supply remains constrained the lack of demand causes prices to drop (global economic downturn). 

The dollar's only value is its perceived value (backed by the full faith and credit of the United States government). However, if a full-blown monetary crisis ensues, it may cause a reversion back to the gold standard. A crisis could also move the world away from the dollar altogether, but there are no truly viable alternatives.

I believe a decentralized blockchain (Bitcoin) is the ultimate solution and will represent a major leap forward in the advancement of human financial markets, in a digital era.  This transition will be gradual and met with a significant amount of resistance from the traditional pillars of the financial market.","comment_ast":{"type":"root","children":[{"type":"user","params":{"name":"akikostas","link":"/u/akikostas/"}},", These are all great questions about the future but no one knows the future for certain. 

The dollar's growing value is related both to the disparity in monetary conditions (U.S. Federal Reserve tightening more than its counterparts) but also, more simply, it reflects a shortage of dollars.  Most commodities are priced and settled in dollars, so when inflation spirals, buying commodities requires more dollars.  But since inflation also causes the Federal Reserve to reduce the supply of dollars to contain inflation domestically, this dynamic can spiral into a monetary crisis.  Japan is trying to devalue the dollar by increasing its supply via selling Treasuries. But while this may help Japan in the short term, this also has the consequence of keeping commodity prices higher for longer. Since the central banks of the UK and Japan have chosen to fight inflation with more monetary easing, this means that for the foreseeable future, inflation continues.  The more inflation spirals higher the worst things get. Once the public expects more inflation, it becomes a self-fulfilling prophecy.  People save less and spend more because they know their dollars will become worth less over time.  People demand more pay, which in turn leads to higher prices for longer.  Companies raise prices with the expectation of inflation.  The spiral gets worse and worse and worse over time. There are only two solutions to spiraling inflation that do not involve making it worse. One is increasing the supply of commodities (not easy to do in an increasingly hostile and deglobalized world, also this will have negative climate change implications) or to crush demand so severely that even though supply remains constrained the lack of demand causes prices to drop (global economic downturn). 

The dollar's only value is its perceived value (backed by the full faith and credit of the United States government). However, if a full-blown monetary crisis ensues, it may cause a reversion back to the gold standard. A crisis could also move the world away from the dollar altogether, but there are no truly viable alternatives.

I believe a decentralized blockchain (Bitcoin) is the ultimate solution and will represent a major leap forward in the advancement of human financial markets, in a digital era.  This transition will be gradual and met with a significant amount of resistance from the traditional pillars of the financial market."]},"created_at":"2022-09-29T13:22:14.665794Z","editable_until":"2022-09-29T13:37:14.665794Z","likes_count":1,"user_vote":0,"user":{"id":5878393,"avatars":{"small":"https://s3.tradingview.com/userpics/5878393-xK2D.png","mid":"https://s3.tradingview.com/userpics/5878393-xK2D_mid.png","big":"https://s3.tradingview.com/userpics/5878393-xK2D_big.png","orig":"https://s3.tradingview.com/userpics/5878393-xK2D_orig.png"},"username":"SPY_Master","is_broker":false,"is_pro":true,"is_paid_pro":true,"pro_plan":"pro_premium","broker_plan":null,"is_moderator":false,"is_trial":false,"badges":[{"name":"pro:pro_premium","verbose_name":"Premium"}],"is_online":false},"spam_status":null,"is_hidden":false,"depth":3,"platform":null,"platform_link_url":null,"platform_link_text":null,"coins":null},{"id":9246894,"parent_id":9242658,"root_id":9239858,"comment":"@SPY_Master, Thank you so much for your reply!! To see how Bitcoin may do we can look at its chart. You can apply Fibonacci levels to the log-adjusted version of Bitcoinâ€™s all-time history index chart.

In my opinion, I see a major bounce potential at the 3.618 level. Though if we see a major financial crisis in the years to come, the 3.414 and 3.272 levels are possible, too. I would expect that any further downside is not sufficiently likely to entertain seriously.

Perhaps in the midst of an insane level of panic could Bitcoin unwind all the way back down to the 3rd Fibonacci extension: e.g. during a major global financial crisis and a major war, the U.S. government decides to ban all mining and use of Bitcoin. Then perhaps we'll get to the 3rd Fibonacci extension ($1226). However, not even the U.S. government can stop Bitcoin's log growth curve. That is because it is a decentralized cryptocurrency. Love hearing your insight from shipping container data. It's telling of the extent of slowdown we should expect in the quarters to come. I definitely agree that inflation has cooled -- but at the same time inflation is not cooling quite as fast as would be needed to avoid chaos in the bond markets from interest rate hikes. That is a major problem, among others. A thought experiment for you: To what extent does the unemployment rate correlate to the cost to ship a container?

I usually draw my Fibonacci levels either using (1) the entire price history or (2) based on important fractal bottoms and tops that define cycles. There are numerous valid ways to draw them. You're not incorrect to draw them without log adjustment, but mathematically they should be log adjusted. You can much better visualize Fibonacci spirals and logistic curves with log adjustment. Actually, all I ever see in my charts are Fibonacci spirals. They're everywhere. So for me not to use log adjustment on my charts would be to obscure the mathematical functions that guide price movements. 

Retracements can be visualized as you do with 1 on top and 0 on bottom, but retracement can also be visualized as Fibonacci extensions being retraced, which puts 0 at the bottom of an important prior fractal low, 1 at the top of that prior fractal high, and retracement as some distant extension of that fractal being retraced. Basically, this method allows me to measure an entire S-curve, and since price is fractal, it in turn also allows me to approximate the peak of the next Fibonacci spiral.","comment_ast":{"type":"root","children":[{"type":"user","params":{"name":"louistran_016","link":"/u/louistran_016/"}},", Love hearing your insight from shipping container data. It's telling of the extent of slowdown we should expect in the quarters to come. I definitely agree that inflation has cooled -- but at the same time inflation is not cooling quite as fast as would be needed to avoid chaos in the bond markets from interest rate hikes. That is a major problem, among others. A thought experiment for you: To what extent does the unemployment rate correlate to the cost to ship a container?

I usually draw my Fibonacci levels either using (1) the entire price history or (2) based on important fractal bottoms and tops that define cycles. There are numerous valid ways to draw them. You're not incorrect to draw them without log adjustment, but mathematically they should be log adjusted. You can much better visualize Fibonacci spirals and logistic curves with log adjustment. Actually, all I ever see in my charts are Fibonacci spirals. They're everywhere. So for me not to use log adjustment on my charts would be to obscure the mathematical functions that guide price movements. 

Retracements can be visualized as you do with 1 on top and 0 on bottom, but retracement can also be visualized as Fibonacci extensions being retraced, which puts 0 at the bottom of an important prior fractal low, 1 at the top of that prior fractal high, and retracement as some distant extension of that fractal being retraced. Basically, this method allows me to measure an entire S-curve, and since price is fractal, it in turn also allows me to approximate the peak of the next Fibonacci spiral."]},"created_at":"2022-09-23T15:36:43.155833Z","editable_until":"2022-09-23T15:51:43.155833Z","likes_count":1,"user_vote":0,"user":{"id":5878393,"avatars":{"small":"https://s3.tradingview.com/userpics/5878393-xK2D.png","mid":"https://s3.tradingview.com/userpics/5878393-xK2D_mid.png","big":"https://s3.tradingview.com/userpics/5878393-xK2D_big.png","orig":"https://s3.tradingview.com/userpics/5878393-xK2D_orig.png"},"username":"SPY_Master","is_broker":false,"is_pro":true,"is_paid_pro":true,"pro_plan":"pro_premium","broker_plan":null,"is_moderator":false,"is_trial":false,"badges":[{"name":"pro:pro_premium","verbose_name":"Premium"}],"is_online":false},"spam_status":null,"is_hidden":false,"depth":6,"platform":null,"platform_link_url":null,"platform_link_text":null,"coins":null},{"id":9220719,"parent_id":9220342,"root_id":9192927,"comment":"@SPY_Master, yes i did draw it on log scale, meant to ask on different methods / reason of choosing 0 - 1 reference point on the fib retracement :D

title: Chainlink is about to make a 4000% upside move..
name: without_worries
contents:
IF the month of September closes as is on the BTC pair.

The facts:

>> The monthly chart above has printed a falling wedge pattern since August 2020.

>> On this month, the month of September 2022 that wedge saw a breakout. A good one. A very good one. An absolutely fantastic one actually.

>> IF come October 1st you see that candle print as is, Chainlink is going to make a 4000% upside move according to the flagpole extension.

>> Stochastic RSI crosses up 20 for the first time ever in Chainlinkâ€™s price action history on the Monthly chart.

Donâ€™t even ask me when. I donâ€™t know, no one does.

Ww

You can use this on any time frame. On the monthly it is a big big picture informing you of a big big move is coming.

title: Stellar lumens to $12
name: without_worries
contents:
On the above 4-day chart is a ridiculous prediction. Nonetheless, the foundation is for lack for better word is, solid.

Price action has corrected almost 90% since the month of May 2021. A number of reasons now exist to be bullish . Those are:

1) The â€˜incredible buyâ€™ signal. Definitely not to be ignored on this time frame.

2) Price action now finds itself on the golden ratio at measured from the March 2020 lows to the highs of May 2021.

3) Letâ€™s talk about this perfect Cup and Handle formation. Technically it is text book. The correction thus far is squeezing between the golden ratio and price action resistance. Eventually it will breakout, thatâ€™s your signal.

4) This is a 100x projection.

Is it possible for price action to fall full further? For sure.

Is it probable? An emphatic no.

Ww

Type: trade
Risk: <=6% of portfolio
Timeframe: 6 to 12 months, seriously.
Return: 100x

If bullish in your book means - will go up in the next 24 months - then yes chart is overall bullish - it is in fact down 80%
If you are looking 3 months out - then no, chart is repeating last cycle pretty much to a T and will tend down lower.
There is element of what I call "November Hope for XLM"  both bull runs for XLM started in November and even during bear market in between bull runs  XLM moved up every November. So we are seeing this "November optimism" again now, all in the face of horrible economic conditions and de-risking in the market.
This chart is saying - I am down allot and waiting for economic conditions to change and then I can move up, but until economic conditions change to spark speculation it will not move up, given that supply of XLM is growing - it will fall in value.

title: Updated longterm BTC chart: The road to 1 million.
name: SebastianofMoon
contents:
I am a BTC bull, but I see far too many overly optimistic price projections on tradingview.
They seem to draw an exponential channel, instead of the current one, that is curved.

While of course it can be that BTC goes out of the current channel, and bursts through the upper resistance, thus reverting back to its original exponential trend,
I like to be more conservative. Because as of now, there is still no reason to believe that BTC will do so, only because it has pumped now already 6 months earlier than 4 years ago.

This could just mean that we also reach the peak 6 months earlier.

The fundamental price drivers will remain the halvings and mainstream adoption.

We can also clearly see that the factors between the subsequent peaks is diminishing every time.
From x38 to x16 and now probably to around x6 and so on.

It cannot just continue to do the same increases again and again, then we would have prices of 100 million USD by 2025 or some insane stuff like that.
That is not very scientific but sensationalist, and we should remain realistic here, even if that means being more conservative. Conservative with 1.3 million in 2030 LOL.
Try telling that someone in the stockmarket hehehe!

Anyways, there is indeed the chance that BTC leaves this channel and creates a faster rising one, but the future datapoints are not here yet, so we must use
the past points for extrapolation.

But no matter what happens, I am convinced that BTC mainstream adoption WILL happen. It's not an "if" question, but a "when" question.

Comment: It will get interesting now, how fast btc will be in making new all-time highs. It might take a little longer than on this chart, maybe by the end of 2021, and maybe "only" 100k instead of 120k.
But then again, it might also surprise us, and indeed reach ATH in July. It all depends now on the growth dynamics of the next months.

Comment: I decided to start a youtube channel, mostly for fun.
Here is my first video:

https://youtu.be/nhhdIx6Am3Y

Comment: Re-uploaded because there was a problem with HD processing:

https://youtu.be/lBMD3QyoYnc

(when I kept saying that we were probably doing an A-B-C-correction and everyone was screaming: "To the Moon!")
But for me they are not pessimistic, but realistic.
Why should you buy Bitcoin on the neck line of a H&S pattern
only not to miss out the infinitesimal chance that it suddenly rises to 120k from there? ;-)
Common sense tells me it won't. What's more, common sense tells me that it will fall from there.

So at the moment I just don't see a reasonable setup for a trade on BTC that would be worth it.

Of course I can be wrong with that. But I do not force my view of things on anyone. Just sharing my thoughts. ;-) Good luck out there.

If 1 BTC is at a million then the total value of bitcoin would be around 21 Trillion. 
To put that into comparison the total amount of US Currency is somewhere around 1.5 trillion (physical cold hard cash). US currency isn't backed by anything (like bitcoin) and used for similar "untraceable" purposes, only difference is one is physical, one is digital. Total currency in circulation (all currencies) is around 5ish trillion.
But then again the value of the entire US stock market is around 50 Trillion, global market is around 90 Trillion (well above the amount of total currency in circulation). 
Total world wealth is like 360 trillion, is it really possible for 1 cryptocurrency to make up a whole number percentage of that?
So in a sense, money is just made up, and there's a lot more of it then hard cash, I guess. So maybe the 21 Trillion bitcoin target is feasible. But if looking at it as a currency, maybe it's not feasible?
Fuck it, I'm putting my life savings on it. I'm only in my 20's so I'll have time to make that back, upside is likely outweighing the downside (I hope).","comment_ast":{"type":"root","children":["IDK about the road to a million. title: S&P EMAs at Historical Critical Point
name: JD_Trader14
contents:
CME_MINI:ES1!

So I opened the chart at the weekend and flicked through the time frames and upon punching the Weekly I noticed the 21EMA and the 89EMAs were pretty tight. I decided the rest of the morning looking through the historical relationship of these two EMAs. It turns out that each time the 21EMA has come down to the 89EMA, there has been a violent reaction. In general, when there are moderate to minimal macros effecting the markets, this reaction represents a strong opportunity to long. In fact, the 21EMA has never dipped below the 89EMA and recovered until months to years later. On the flip side, on the two occasions the 21EMA did dip below the 89EMA, was in 2001 and 2008...two very significant moments in market history.

I also noted that once the break happens the S&P tends to bottom at around 40%-50% of that breaking point. If we were to use today's valuation, a 45% drop from today is around 2200. That is also the bottom of the COVID crash i.e. where the real market was going to be trading before infinite stimulus was provided by the Fed.

I found this interesting as it seems in these troubling times and with a 'nuclear winter' around the corner in Europe, there is a real macro concern for markets. I'm leaning bearish and I think this rally will fail like every rally this year and lead the 21EMA below the 89EMA. Obviously, I react to the chart and should there be a strong reaction off the touch upwards, I will be flipping bullish .

Trade active: The bears are out in force and the 21EMA has already started to drop below the 89EMA. This price action going into Q4 is extremely bearish. Winter in Europe is forecasted to be a tough one, to put it mildly, and the markets are preparing for a recession. The CPI figures leave the FED with no option but to keep hiking rates and frankly, the populace has accepted we are in for a tough time. Now is the time for the FED to be aggressive in tackling inflation. The quicker we get into a recession, the quicker we can adjust to get back out of it. The longer we delay, the more likely a depression / stagflation event occurs.

The next two weeks will determine price action for the foreseeable future. Successive weeks of the 21EMA below the 89EMA, going into end of week, month and quarter is a very bearish indication.

Stay safe.

Comment: This is a sellers market. 21 EMA has dropped below the 89EMA convincingly. Furthermore, the price has dropped below the 200EMA. This, again, is extremely bearish PA. A reclaim by end of the week is needed by the bulls to save the day. If not, historically, a 40% drop is probable.

Trade active: Q3 closed with yearly lows. This weekly/monthly/quarterly couldnt be more bearish ðŸ». Not only has the 21EMA crossed the 89EMA on the weekly but the price rejected off the 200EMA. The last time this happened was in March 2008 prior to a 48% drop.
There will probably be rallies in the coming weeks to try and reclaim the 200EMA so there is upside potential but the trend is your friend in these conditions. Outlook remains bearish and this is a sellers market.

Hikes will continue into 2023 as Powell mentioned, the US posted a 3rd consecutive quarter with negative GDP growth, Russia annexing 4 Ukrainian regions + they're Nato application on top of a very very cold and expensive winter for our European cousins. If you're bullish I salute you.
Comment:
Comment: Keeping shorts open but also opened some longs. I think we rally something like this.

Comment: Bulls couldn't reclaim the 200ema last week and the macro is so negative that there is zero attempt to even try again this week.
This market hasn't truly priced in a recession. The next 2 quarters will see a re-pricing across all asset classes. Capitulation in major stocks probably happens in 2023 and a long accumulation phase will start off the back of those lows.

Trade active: It's over boys.
I hope whoever saw this took the trade.
See you at the bottom.

title: TSLA STILL A BUY!!!!
name: ShortSeller76
contents: Historically low RSI for TSLA is 30, we are at 30, at support next support is $216. We are going into a new moon phase which will help push TSLA up. Pierced bollinger bands , low stochastics, still in an uptrend, golden cross printing 50dma through 200dma, this is nothing more than an opportunity to ADD as I did this morning. We should see $215-334 in coming weeks.
Comment: Added more calls, total of 70. TSLA is oversold at it's highest level in history, we have many oversold indicators and a new moon printing.

title: BOUNCE ?, ONLY IF 357 CAN HOLD
name: abigreen
contents:
After touching 357 ( double bottom ) yesterday and testing it again in premarket, SPY should bounce.
Like I mentioned yesterday, I don't expect large bounce, my target is 364-367.
I don't think I am going to play it, Ill wait for another short entry instead.
If we brake support at 357, I expect SPY falling very sharply and quickly.

Bulls need to brake 360 first, then 364
Bears need to brake 357 support

Good luck !

Comment: Short dip below 357,
Bulls took over and are trying to defend it, SPY must stay above 360 to prevent freefall. We are trading on 200EMA on weekly. Failure to defend it will be really bad
Comment: okey, we'll get to my first target today, 364
Comment: WOW, didnt have the time to get in, lol
Comment: Was 363 max?

title: US500 next moves
name: LPI_Investments
contents:
The next moves of the US500:

1) The price moves towards the $ 3.9k (+ 8%) zone, finding the technical resistance (red box) and then goes down to the $ 3.2k zone (-16%)

2) The current support is invalidated and the price drops directly to the $ 3.2k zone (-9.5%)

3) The price will find a lot of volatility with the next data coming out of the CPI - Inflation rate:
Thursday October 13 '22 at 8.30 am in October NY time.


LPI , grow with us.

title: Gold on the path to test #1,600.80 once again as expected
name: goldenBear88
contents:
Gold's general commentary: Gold was in the middle of the #11-Month Neutral zone made by the last consolidation phase (April #15 - June #15) before it made itâ€™s August peak. As discussed before, when Gold Trades within that zone, in most cases according to the cycle, Price-action always delivers Medium-term Selling opportunity on the aftermath. I have mentioned that current relief rally will be short-lived and that Gold will deliver decent Medium-term Selling opportunity towards #1,600.80 psychological mark once again.


Technical analysis: On a Short-term perspective and regarding the Daily chart , there is an interesting development with the RSI indicator on a Bearish Divergence (BD) with the Price-action as it is on Lower High's Upper zone since September #26, while the Price-action is on Higher Low's Upper zone at the moment. Similar sequence has happened both from January #11 - #16 and February #16 - #20. Both led to a #3-session peak above the Hourly 4 chart's Resistance in form of the recovery, then Selling opportunity has been delivered. Hourly 4 chartâ€™s Resistance is currently seen Trading at #1,682.80 on Spot prices. If thatâ€™s the case, todayâ€™s E.U. session will be followed with thin Volume , and as U.S. session is approaching with more Volatility / consolidation, I can expect Sellers to re-appear and push Gold as Low as they can, following the positive DX sentiment due NFP not missing the estimate.(on main stage tomorrow). I will exercise caution since market structure is tight today and tomorrow, while my Medium-term Selling orders (above #1,700.80) are looking great at this point.


Fundamental analysis: Important Trading Week for Gold ahead as the traditional Volatility is visible on the markets (for more than #14 sessions sharp ) as Fed (doing the same manoeuvre continously to postpone, but not to prevent the final crash) is deal with Repurchase agreements scheme and inventing such thing as â€œFederal Debt ceilingâ€, as discussed many times is traditional Fed's practise as they are about to pass another huge Bill (which will be released shortly) and their main aim is to remove the publicâ€™s attention from huge disastrous Bill they are about to pass, and shift it towards Debt ceiling issue. This is Inflation data and always keep in mind Gold's use as a counter to Inflation , but with current hyperinflation growing on Daily basis, I do not see Gold as sustainable sole asset as hedge against it. From #20 - #30 sessions aspect and point of view, if chart is consulted (observing September #3 Highâ€™s and September #30 Lowâ€™s similarities from few Years back), it is obvious why the Price-action was caught in middle of multi-Month Neutral Rectangle .


My position: Gold is Trading on my predicted values and currently the path is clear towards #1,600.80 psychological mark. Remember the importance of DX in these sessions as I have been waiting DX to find the Support and start recovering (to start re-Selling Gold on Intra-day basis) as DX determines Gold's Short and Medium-term direction. I have utilized current Selling sequence since #1,720's as I don't have aim to stop. My Medium-term Selling orders are running nicely as I have engaged additional Selling order (#1,670.80 entry point) towards #1,652.80 mark first, then #1,642.80 Support in extension.

title: USDJPY - Daily Trade Idea - 11-Oct-22
name: onelinkFX
contents:
USDJPY (LONG)- If all the support holds in place.

If we see the Support broken out then we could see the shift in the trend.

I marked the TP 1 (20 pips), TP 2 (50 pips) , TP 3 (100 pips) and EXIT (SL - 60 pips) on the chart.

(THIS IDEAS VALID NEXT 24 HOURS)

Please note this is only the Trade Idea base on S & R and not a signal, the market can react differently during the session due to News Impact and only enter if we have the final confirmation for entry.
- Rejection Candle Formation - Green Candle after the Red Candle.
- Stochastic - Oversold Area

title: Bitcoin â€“ the new bull trap is incoming!
name: SkyrexTrading
contents:
Hello, everyone!

Two days ago I gave you an idea about the mid-term analysis on Bitcoin . Briefly, I am waiting for the last bearish leg down. Before it I made the local analysis on the 1h timeframe using the Trading Chaos approach and I was quite successful. One year ago I red 3 books about the Trading Chaos and make a conclusion that its useless theory. But one month ago I decided to study this approach again and found that I was unexperienced to understand it in the correct way Now I am practicing in this approach on the local 1h timeframe because I need short-term strategy. On the 1D timeframe I am successful, but it is not sufficient for me. Today I am going to continue analyzing the local timeframe using Trading Chaos.

Letâ€™s take a look at the 1h timeframe BTCUSDT chart of the WhiteBit exchange. We can find here the completed 1-2-3-4-5 Elliott waves cycle. The divergence with the Awesome oscillator confirms this idea. Today the price crossed above the Williams Alligator indicatorâ€™s balance (red) line, which means the market is in correction right now. The maximum target for the correction is the Fibonacci golden pocket ~ $19900 before the new crash. It looks like the bull trap is incoming because now the crowd is not disappointed and think that the market can start the bull rally in every moment. This is the signal that we have to wait a little bit more.

Best regards, Ivan
